column2: With foreign rulers come foreign influences. The local culture in the county of [Root.GetName] has evolved over time into something new, and the people living there are no longer referred to as Picts.

Far from their ancestral Northern lands, the Lombards have over the centuries slowly but steadily adopted more and more Latin and Roman traditions. In the county of [Root.GetName], the people have now gone so far as to start considering themselves properly Italian.

The lowlands near the mouth of the Rhine have long been a crossroads where empires and cultures meet. In the county of [Root.GetName] a new identity now seems to be appearing. They are no longer [Root.Culture.GetName], but Dutch.
The traditionally Saxon population of the county of [Root.GetName] has with time and under foreign rule become more and more similar to their Germanic cousins.
The Franks in the county of [Root.GetName] have now adopted enough of Latin customs that they can no longer be recognized as Germanic. The scholars call them 'French'.
Under Latin influence, the Visigothic population in the county of [Root.GetName] have now adopted new speech and new customs, becoming Occitan in culture.

The Visigoths in various regions are slowly developing unique local identities with distinctive speech and customs. The latest news is that the county of [Root.GetName] has become Castilian in culture.
The Visigoths in various regions are slowly developing unique local identities with distinctive speech and customs. The latest news is that the county of [Root.GetName] has become Catalan in culture.
Through foreign trade and Visigothic influence new traditions are evolving among the Suebi. This is highly noticeable in the county of [Root.GetName], which is now Portuguese in culture.
The dynamic society in Muslim Spain is giving rise to a new cultural identity. Thus the people in the county of [Root.GetName] are now calling themselves Andalusian.
The people in the county of [Root.GetName] have assimilated new customs from afar, blending them with old Slavic traditions. They have also taken to calling themselves 'Rus' or 'Russians'.
They are Scottish now!
New times, new customs.
Dutch people? Interesting.
They are Germans now.
Such are the times.
Occitans, I see...
The times are changing.
The times are changing.
The times are changing.
Something distinct and truly Spanish.
New, but still recognizable.
